posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26173971
It's okay, but it's weak, regular oil changes (every 5k) gets them longer, and, even more importantly, ensuring proper cooling. Heat does crack the heads.
Mine has 250kkm, and with the recent overhaul it doesn't blow any smoke.

Fun fact: the RD28 is in essence a stroked RB26, with SOHC and a head built for Diesel. Big parts of it are originally designed for gasoline, and they were only reinforced just enough to not explode at Diesel-level compression.

An RB26DETT should fit directly (mounting points and bellhousing) though, so it's basically a lifted GTR. With 120hp.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I did this, and then back to Denver, in 2009 in a busted up 1986 Nissan pickup. It had a completely broken suspension by the time I got back. Fucking Mexican speed bumps man. Oh also this was before internet driving directions existed south of the border and I didn't have a cell phone so there was a lot of guessing where I was and where to go.
The top speed of my truck was 62 mph and it took ages to get there (this turned out to be because a large towel was eventually found to be stuffed in the air intake).
Some things of note along the way include driving through Nuevo Laredo during peak cartel activity, I was very nervous until I got to Monterrey as travel in the region was considered extremely hazardous.
In Honduras I had a breakdown, the exhaust started blowing thick black smoke and eventually the engine died. I found the intake full of oil. I cleaned it all out and that was the end of it; my theory was some very bad roads put the truck at such extreme angles that my (bad) PCV sent a bunch of oil into the intake.
Also in Honduras I had to cross a river where there was a sudden drop off that swallowed nearly the entire vehicle. On the advice of a local I was fording the river in reverse which turned out to be helpful in that I was able to shut the engine off before it was submerged. I was able to get a local farmer to drag the truck out with his tractor and once it was dry it started right up again.
Lots of issues with police in Honduras in particular; lots of roadblocks and bribe requests.
On the way back up through Mexico, an entire region was flooded and I drove a couple hundred miles through between 6 inches and 2 feet of water. Eventually the truck had enough of the water and just died and I was stranded. After about 4 hours it started up again and I was able to carry on.
I got back to the States and sold the truck for $1800, after paying $1100 for it a few months earlier although it was much worse for wear and like I mentioned, the suspension was trash

The F350 uses radius control arms up front. They don't flex as well as three or four link but are more stable on the highway and better at handling heavy loads. From the factory most solid front axle pickup trucks are tuned for highway, not off road.

Also the idea that solid front axle is better for off road comes form its ability to easily be modified to flex with suspension upgrades. IFS can be very expensive and complicated to achieve the same flex you can easily get out of a solid axle.

People don't understand how much of a shithole USSR was and Russia is.
In the USSR when you got married the state gave you a car for your honeymoon.
It was just for the honeymoon. When the honeymoon was over they took the car back.
My Russian high-school teacher was a translator for the Russian vice president (this was like '93 or something).
He showed him a Walmart and the VP thought it was propaganda bullshit, that the store was filled with items and people shopping just for him to see.
When my teacher showed him my school he didn't understand why there were so many cars. When he was told they were the students he refused to believe that kids had their own cars.

Russians were content with the Lada because just owning a car was an amazing feat in life.

squid basically means doin it wrong on a sports bike

The definition varies from person to person because everyone does something wrong but thinks it isn't wrong.

A Harley wannabe motorcycle gang dentist is not a squid. A guy on a sport bike who doesn't know how to ride, has the wrong accessories, has the wrong gear, or is otherwise being a poseur is a squid. Doing something right doesn't make someone not a squid. A stunter popping wheelies on the highway in shorts, tee and flip flops is still a squid.

Being not a squid requires being in appropriate AGATT (anyone who wears more than me is wrong, anyone who wears less than me is wrong. It requires being on an appropriate bike for the kind of riding, but this only applies in the larger direction (anyone who rides a bigger bike than me is wrong). It requires being of appropriate skill (one direction only, anyone less skilled than me is a squid) and attitude (anyone that rides more aggressively or more like a hooligan than me is wrong, anyone who rides more conservatively than me is wrong)

>>26179803
Do you want
>Genuine engine performance improvement
>Remove likely hideously huge and ugly stick exhaust
If it's the latter, just get a slip on. If you're looking for performance, get a full system. Be advised if you do a full system you will need an ECU tuner installed on modern bikes, which you will either need to learn to do or pay a shop to do. It's an expensive process, you need to buy the full system, the tuner, and pay for the tune. Then you you need to pay labor, which you can save a little bit on if you put the pipes on yourself. Also, if you just like to cruze be advised some full exhaust systems can be uncomfortably loud.

>>26176691
Model T wasn't the first gas car. Before the Model T which opened up car ownership to the middle class of the era, cars had been an expensive impractical novelty for the upper class for about 20 years. Even once the Model T arrived there really wasn't infrastructure to support it, so Ford sold people the ability to make fuel for it at home so they could drive around, even if it was just in their local area. It took a while longer for the prices to really come down, and for the infrastructure to be at a point where car ownership wasn't just something for well to do early adopters interested in new technology.

Tesla Roadster, the first modern EV, which like those first gas cars was an expensive novelty of the upper class, was only 14 years ago.
Over that time the price for ~60kWh EVs has come down from $80k to $25k, and that $25k car is a lot more practical vehicle for about the same inflation adjusted price as the first Model T.
Also remember, by modern standards the Model T wouldn't be a car with its 45mph top speed. It would be a UTV, and there are comparable cheap electric UTVs already on the market.

>>26176858
>So you finally admit it's more like a hybrid than a BEV.
I'm not sure why you think this is a 'gotcha'. Hybrid Electric Vehicles, especially Plug In Hybrid Electric Vehicles are Electric Vehicles. Nobody gets caught up on the 'purity' of the powertrain, especially when talking about powertrain development to conform to the reality of racing rulebooks which allow hydrogen refueling but not battery swapping. One of the advantages of electric powertrains is their ability to take advantage of multiple sources of electricity, and an endurance racing EV using a swappable high capacity battery would still have a similar design with a buffer battery for peak performance, and the KERS.

>will last for less than half an hour at the average power consumption of 120 kW (that's 160 horsepower), leaving you with fuel-cell's 85 kW (114 hp)
Except that's not how it works. The 85kW fuel cell is continually generating electricity, so any time the car is drawing more power than that the fuel cell can provide its drawing on the power stored in the buffer battery, and any time the car is drawing less power than that, the fuel cell is filling the buffer battery back up. Also any time the car is decelerating its using the KERS to put energy back into the buffer battery.
As I said, this is very similar to how endurance racing performance hybrids work, and why they're so dominant because the battery acts as a buffer to keep the generator in a lower stress state.

Considering how much higher performance the N Vision 74's motors are, and how much better the Kinetic Energy Recovery they can provide is compared to the Prius, it would still almost certainly be able to outpace it. Even the new sportier Prius.
Keep in mind the Hyundai car we're talking about isn't a racing optimized vehicle built to be lightweight, its a retro luxury concept show car for this powertrain.
If Hyundai do decide to take this powertrain to LeMans it will almost certainly be in a prototype shell.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26177373
>Electric motors in transmissionless vehicles
There are no "transmissionless" vehicles. They have fixed gear transmissions. This works for electric motors because their torque band is so wide. Enough to manage the whole range of normal speeds a typical vehicle will be driven. Which is why the only vehicles that need specially designed motors with varied windings or multiple transmissions are ones with top speeds over about 140mph.

>it's a hybrid electric vehicle
Its not because Fuel Cells are a fully electric powertrain element. Hybrids are hybrids because there are two separate dissimilar powertrains.
Every Fuel Cell Electric Vehicle must have a hydrogen tank, fuel cell stack, battery, and an electric motor. The fuel cell provides a constant electrical current, the battery takes that current and buffers it to provide peak power on demand and handles kinetic energy recovery from the electric motor.
The only difference with the Hyundai concept compared to the Toyota Mirai FCEV is that the buffer battery is much larger, 60kWh vs 8kWh, giving it the ability to drive in a full battery electric mode without needing to use hydrogen in daily use.
Which is a big deal when hydrogen costs the equivalent of $15 a gallon.

Your nitpicks are based on your ignorance of the technology. My post comparing EVs to ICE was in terms of the limitations in stored energy currently.
That is the one advantage internal combustion has right now. The ability to easily store 1MWh in an endurance racing fuel tank, and get another 1MWh relatively quickly.
BEVs typically have less than 100kWh, one tenth the stored energy, and lack the equivalent of an endurance racing fuel tank.
This is the reason why Fuel Cell Range Extending technology is in the process of being approved for endurance racing.
It allows for fully electric vehicles with comparable range and refueling times.

Correct.
>This works for electric motors because their torque band is so wide.
Not so wide, torque drops significantly with revs. And, if I'm not mistaken, the slower you get the less is the ability to regen brake.

>Hybrids are hybrids because there are two separate dissimilar powertrains.
Dunno about "dissimilar powertrains", the definition usually is "more than one power source". The said Prius has a single powertrain assembly incorporating motor-generators and ICE, which can't function independently. Other hybrid setups have those separated, but that does not matter because there are two sources of power: chemical fuel and electric traction battery.
>Its not because Fuel Cells are a fully electric powertrain element.
It's electrochemical, it oxidises fuel like an ICE does but instead of mechanical work it produces potential difference which can be converted to electrical current.
>The only difference with the Hyundai concept compared to the Toyota Mirai FCEV is that the buffer battery is much larger, 60kWh vs 8kWh, giving it the ability to drive in a full battery electric mode without needing to use hydrogen in daily use.
I think I understand your point. Current production cars with ICE and a small traction battery are called hybrid-electric vehicles, the ones with a larger battery (that can be charged externally) are called plug-in hybrid-electric vehicles, so how should we call FCEVs with larger batteries if they make it into production? PFCEVs?

>Your nitpicks are based on your ignorance of the technology. My post comparing EVs to ICE was in terms of the limitations in stored energy currently.
Nope, I and other anon(s) saw those posts as an attempt to present current limitations of the battery technology as already solved (or solvable in two more weeks) by a technology not related to the battery tech at all. Hence wishful thinking and false comparisons accusations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26174258
Because it's not properly explained so people just repeat it wrong. Back pressure was required because fuel had lower octanes which allowed the gasses to reignite from the heat of the pipe, that's why loud bangs from car exhausts were common back then. It was a safety feature to have an exhaust system that expelled the gasses in a fast way so if there was an ignition it wouldn't be inside the exhaust system only at the end, increasing the life expectancy of your car

When 90 and above octanes became the norm the back pressure stopped being necessary, this means the width of the exhaust system is the actual important part of it to make the engine be efficient and that, as you can see, is not back pressure

posts.com: It's less that motorcycles kill people with accidents and more that the people who were inclined to die in auto accidents anyway gravitate towards motorcycles. If I get hit, it will do more damage to me compared to being in a car, but given that I have better acceleration, braking, and maneuverability in addition to being a smaller target I consider it less likely that I will be hit compared to being in a car. Like a game where I'm putting my points into dodge instead of armor or something.

Get some Mobil 1 5 quart jug of 5W-20 and a nice extended life filter for $10 or so, these motors aren't run hard enough as daily drivers even in hot areas to thin out the oil and hurt the motor, I wouldn't go any thicker than 5W-30 if you're gonna beat on the car, and don't go over 5000 miles on the oil change to keep everything happy. >>26165936
that's kinda expensive for where I live but I don't know the market in your country
the facelift from 2006 to 2008 has a few improvements like a revised aux belt route that won't eat pulley and alternator bearings, exhaust manifold replaced under warranty with a cast one that doesn't crack, larger front brakes and a bunch of other little things, but both are solid cars.
the engine is solid, but use 0w30 oil only and service it regularly, I do mine every 5000km or twice yearly
fuel system is temperamental if you use aftermarket fuel filters, they're not rated for the same flow as OEM denso or Bosch
I've had mine for 5 years and the only faults I've had are worn out bushings, sticking rear brake pistons and a failing alternator

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I don't recommend anyone get a German car from this era unless it's your weekend project car that you can leave on Jack stands sitting the week while you are waiting for parts and then drive something else to work during the week. Unless that is your situation, you shouldn't but a car like this because it is going to break down on you. It 100% needs repairs that will be very expensive if you pay a mechanic. In 3 years I've only taken my e36 to a mechanic 3 times because I do most of the work myself. I was not able to do 3 jobs in my garage. 1, replacing the rear lower control arms. 2 replacing the lock system module after it locked the doors shut, 3 reattaching the exhaust manifold after I did a full engine rebuild. For these jobs you need special tools and or a proper lift. To reattach the exhaust, they had to lift the car and then drop the engine down. There is no other way to access the studs. And that doesn't get into the dozens of jobs I did myself. Brakes, coolant system rebuild, entire cylinder head rebuild and timing, new clutch master and slave cylinder, new tie rods etc etc. I'm not saying these repairs are a big deal, but a car that old will need them and will be expensive unless you can do them yourself. Tbh the parts themselves are not crazy expensive but labor tends to make shitty so expensive.

Actually a few weeks ago my coworker told me it cost him 700 dollars to replace one control arm and 6 spark plugs and coil packs on his Lexus. I looked up the parts on rock auto, even if he went with top end parts, it was under 200 for everything, but you add labor, 120 bucks an hour and honestly he's lucky it was as cheap as it was. Mechanics are not going to rush a repair for you.

>>26176123
In the context of an engine, torque is the amount of work it performs per complete revolution of the crankshaft, and power is just that factored into time
For an analogy:
>you're loading identical boxes into a truck
>torque is the amount of boxes you carry per trip
>power is how many boxes you can load per minute

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Torque is what you feel, it's what pushes you back into your seat. If you swapped two different engines into your car but kept everything else the same - one with more low end torque and on with more high RPM power - and you did a 2nd gear pull, the low end torque motor would feel faster because it makes mote torque.

But if you use gearing, the high RPM motor can deliver more torque to the wheels. In order to go the same speed, the torque motor might have to be in 3rd gear, while the high RPM motor is in second. If you did another pull with the torque motor in the 3rd, the RPM motor in second would feel faster because the gearing allows it to deliver more torque to the wheels.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Torque is a measure of force over distance. Horse power is torque over a period of time. In an engineering sense. 1 ftlbs is the amount of force to move a 1lbs object 1 foot. Horse power was created as an example of the work a machine could do over a given period of time, when compared to a horse. A spinning motor makes torque, as the measure of force it can do. How many times that motor can exert that force in a set amount of time, normally a minute, is the Horse Power rating.

You can have a powerful motor with a 1000flbs of torque but if it spins at a low RPM, it's HP rating won't be that high. While you could have a small engine with low torque but spins at really high RPM, it has it would have high HP.

In your basic, I don't know anything about it, terms. Torque is how much weight you could potentially move, hp is how fast it can move that weight.
I know that is technically incorrect, guys, but that's the basic way of explaining it. In car terms to non car people.

posts.com: Can you air cool an engine by driving it around winter temps with the hood removed?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: How can a Hoosier such as myself renew an expired driver's license with no utility bills to use as proof of address?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26156267
no, because the cylinders are well insulated from the exterior surface of the engine by the void cast into the engine which is called the "water jacket". cylinders in a water cooled engine lack the ability to transfer heat away unless in direct contact with water/coolant. also, the cylinder head depends on coolant passages as well, since it doesn't have enough surface area to lose heat via radiation or convection. keep in mind that the specific heat of water is much higher than that of air, meaning water can absorb and transfer heat much more efficiently than air. water cooling is considered better since you can easily maintain a controlled and uniform temperature throughout the engine, and it's easier to design a large powerful engine when you don't have to account for bulky external cooling fins.

an air cooled engine has the cylinder in close contact with the exterior of the engine, which is finned like a heat sink for air to be blown across. main advantage being simplicity, as there's no "cooling system" that can fail and leave you stranded (coolant leaks out, water pump belt breaks, etc) but the operating temperature of the engine is harder to control for different operating environments and loads, so the engine life is relatively shorter, and specific power output is relatively lower.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26156267
ideally the radiators for water and oil cooling should have access to fresh air from outside of the engine bay, and dump their heat outside of the engine bay.
radiators can be remotely mounted .ie with longer tubes to position them more for better airflow. (don't ask me about pump head pressure tho lmao)
and proper use of ducting can prevent debris and insects from building up on the radiators.

other parts in the engine bay are air cooled and more confined in their access to fresh air, .eg fuel rails, fuse boxes, coil packs, alternator, battery
such parts are more dependant on the engine bays ambient temperature, but passive ventilation such as hood vents may be sufficient
but water and dust must be kept away from delicate components, so the vents should be placed with great care.

since you are driving in winter some of your engines parts may become too cold, or too wet. many older cars include muffs and baffles to deal with winter conditions.
and particularly in winter you must make sure that when you are stuck in traffic or driving up hill that your cars main ventilation fan is working,
I had an electric radiator fan whose thermostat had burnt out from being overworked, later replaced with a manual switch as a quick fix.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26156478
yeah but those trucks and your explorer were full of coolant being constantly circulated by the water pump thru the engine & heater core, even with the thermostat closed. if you couldn't get cabin heat at -10 your thermostat is stuck open, or heater core is blocked.

the outcome of driving with no coolant depends on the specific engine i suppose, but eventually it will get too hot to run and start pinging and knocking heavily. not uncommon to scuff pistons, blow head gaskets, warp/crack cylinder heads due to extremely localized overheating of pistons, bores and exhaust ports. note that peak combustion temperature in a gasoline engine can reach 4000F while the melting temperature of aluminum is only 1200F.

i remember riding a friends honda shadow for more than half an hour without realizing the cooling system was completely dry. ran fine until i slowed down for traffic, then it started pinging really bad and died, would just ping and kick back when trying to start. the temperature gauge stayed in the middle the whole time lol

>It's a really odd smell not related to anything in the car.
my money would be your evaporator drain is clogged and water is sitting in the evap pan and developing mold. find the drain hose and blow it out with compressed air then run some cleaner like simplegreen through the system to clean up the mold.
> do some car condensers for the A/C actually rumble harder than the engin
Your condensor is the radiator like thing on the front of the car and shouldnt make any noise, you're probably thinking of your compressor, the thing that spins attached to the engine. no, it is not normal for it to be vibrating, most likely it is failing and i would replace it before it gets metal shavings throughout your entire AC system, if it hasnt already

posts.com:
>>26168910
I can't really see the hose well in your pic, but get a hose that's made to be used either as fuel line or vacuum line, they sell it at your FLAPS. A regular rubber hose will get soft due to the oil.

Lean codes are often vacuum leaks of some sort. Get a propane torch (for plumbing), turn it on, but don't light it, and idle your car as you run it along all vacuum lines, pcv, intake, boost lines, gaskets, oil cap, dipstick tube, seals, etc. If you hit a spot where the engine speeds up, you've just found your leak.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26170369
Check your fluid level and quality first, could just be low ATF. Also pull codes in case it's some sort of weird sensor problem. Check all fuses. Check your shift linkage, it's possible the transmission is ok the cable that pulls it in gear is just damaged or stretched.
If all else fails, just buy a new transmission and swap it. If you have a lift it's easy as crud, but it can be done with jackstands too. Ebay has used transmissions for your car for $500 delivered, your local junkyard would be half that. Give yourself a weekend and preferably find a friend to help with the lining up, but it can be done alone.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26174775
>>26174796
The twisting motion is the key, you have to twist first that breaks the seal THEN pull out. Don't twist as you pull and don't pull first, twist then pull. You might need to use some hose clamp pliers or put some duct tape on vice grips if you dont have them to increase the grip for the twisting portion. Once it will twist, the pulling is the easy part.

>>26166270
Oh that's not hard actually.
Cadillac exemplified the size-era of luxury auto manufacturing, typically thought of as the period between WWII and 1980.
The post-war economic boon for Americans combined with rapidly scaling infrastructure came together to create the huge, beautiful, and powerful cars that dominated the US market in the 1960s and 1970s.
A whole host of factors relating to emissions, fuel consumption, and economic conditions all brought the size-era to an end, as small economical cars took hold in the American markets in the late 1970s.

1977 was the death of Cadillac, and GM's end to the size-era.

Post-war Cadillac is the Cadillac people remember, and their focus was on luxury and scale.
From 1945 to 1976, Cadillac made their cars bigger, better, faster, and that's all they did.
Add chrome, add cubes, add features, rinse and repeat for 30 years.
Auto-dimming headlamps, self-leveling suspension, power seats with memory settings, dual-reservoir brakes, automatic climate control, bulb-out indicators, Caddies were bad motherfuckers.
The cars themselves just kept getting bigger, with the Sedan de Ville breaking the 230" (19ft 2") mark, and the Series 75, sometimes mistakenly referred to as the Fleetwood, reaching a staggering 252" (21ft) in length.

(1/3)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26166431
At one time, Cadillac was the king of V8 engines.
The first production V8 in a vehicle was a Cadillac L-Head V8. Cadillac also produced the very first American V8 with a cross-plane crankshaft in 1924.
Post-war, Cadillac's OHV V8 design would become the basis for countless other GM engines.
Chevrolet small-block, big-block, and LS engines can all be traced back to the Cadillac OHV engine that earned them Motor Trend Car of The Year in 1949.
Conditions in the 1960s allowed for rapid increases in engine size and capacity.
From 1968 onward, 472 and 500 cubic inch engines become the norm for Cadillac, that's 7.7L - 8.2L.
In 1972 and 1973, the first automotive emissions regulations were put into place in the United States, thus beginning the malaise period of automotive design, and putting the first big nail in the Cadillac coffin.

In 1970, a Cadillac with the 500 cube V8 was putting out over 400 horsepower and over 550 ft lbs of torque, and in the 4,900lb de Ville could net you 12 miles per gallon.
By 1976, changes required to meet emissions brought the massive 8.2L V8 down to a pitiful 190 horsepower and only 360 ft lbs of torque, powering the now 5,400lb de Ville and getting only 8 miles per gallon.
During this time, the cars were still getting larger and more luxurious, with more features being added to distract from the steadily decreasing power and fuel economy.


(2/3)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26166434

A combination of increasing emissions standards, safety standards, and demands for fuel-economy from consumers who had now lived through the 1973 Gas Crisis, all pushed GM to bring an end to the size-era.
30 years of pushing bigger, faster, more luxurious vehicles had finally caught up with the reality of changing global economic conditions.
In 1977, GM began to downsize their vehicles, including the entire Cadillac line-up.
The 1977 DeVille and Fleetwood both featured a smaller 425 cubic inch V8 motor, they both rode on the shorter DeVille chassis.
They were shorter, narrower, and half a ton lighter than they had been before.

From 1977 to the re-birth of Cadillac in 1991, their vehicles continued to become smaller and simpler.
The lists of features stopped growing, as other automakers were catching up or passing them.
No longer was Cadillac home to GM's largest and most powerful engines.
No longer was Cadillac allowed to run rampant with design, the chrome and fins that once defined the appearance of the brand were slowly lost.

The first post-size-era Cadillac was the 1981 Cimarron, the first compact from the brand, and widely regarded as one of the worst vehicles in American automotive history.
Cadillac would continue to fail sideways through the 1980s, and it took the 1991 introduction of the Northstar to revitalize the brand and set the stage for Cadillac as it exists today.

(3/3)

If you'd like to learn more about the size-era, the malaise period, and the distinct global economic conditions that caused them, I'd recommend reading about the US dollar crisis, and the Bretton Woods system. Fun stuff, for white people anyway.

Not enough Cadillac love.

The Cadillac Series 62 "Eldorado" was introduced in 1953.
It was intended as a low production road-going version of the 1952 El Dorado "Golden Anniversary" concept car.
Only 532 were produced.

1967 - The Eighth Generation Eldorado
"It's like having a giant metal penis on wheels, and you get to show it to everyone and they just love it, they're impressed by it, they know your huge metal penis is magnificent and they just can't deny it when it's right there in front of them!"

Cadillac chooses the Eldorado as the name to carry them into the burgeoning personal luxury car market.
The segment was defined by large, powerful coupes designed with excess in mind, creating the cod-piece of the automotive world.
Cadillac redesigned the new 1967 Eldorado as a 2-door, front-engine, front-wheel drive coupe, sharing the E-Body platform with the Buick Riviera and new Oldsmobile Toronado.
At 18'5" in length and 4700lbs, the new Eldorado was a staggering coupe.
For perspective, the current Dodge Charger is 16'8", a shortbed single-cab F150 is 17'6".
The Eldorado featured a Cadillac 429 V8, putting 340 horsepower and 480 ft lbs of torque through the chain-driven Turbo-Hydramatic 425 transmission.
In 1968, that 429 was replaced with the 472 Cadillac V8, making 375 horsepower and 525 ft lbs of torque.
Finally, in 1970, the Eldorado was graced with the big-bad, the massive Cadillac 500.
Making a whopping 400 horsepower and 550ft lbs of torque, the 500 was exclusive to the Eldorado at its introduction.

The 9th generation Eldorado would follow, driving headlong into the malaise period, and bearing the compromises that served to end the size-era of luxury auto manufacturing.

Pictured is a magazine advertisement for the 1967 Cadillac Eldorado.

Remember, your fathers and grandfathers had better lives than you do.
Show your resentment this holiday season with the gift of a Cadillac magazine ad from eBay and a lengthy monologue about Nixon and/or Reagan.
